tutorial.title: Creating Forms
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn how to build your first form in HTML

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
Websites often need to gather user inputs. To gather these inputs, we use forms.

Let's look at a login page for example.

lessons.title: Form Structure
lessons.interactiveContent:
A form element with different input elements and a submit button inside make up the form structure. Code the word form.

Make sure to type form.

lessons.title: Form Element
lessons.interactiveContent:
To create a form, we need the opening <form> and closing </form> tags.

Make sure to pick < followed by form and then >, </, form, >.

lessons.title: Form Inputs
lessons.interactiveContent:
To collect user input, we add input elements inside of the form element. Type the word input in the second field.

Make sure to type input.

lessons.title: Fieldset
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use fieldsets to group related inputs together. A fieldset will display a border around the related elements. Code the fieldset elements.

Make sure to pick <fieldset>, followed by </fieldset>.

lessons.title: Legend
lessons.interactiveContent:
We place a legend element inside the fieldset element to caption the entire field set. Surround the second fieldset with the legend element.

Make sure to pick < followed by legend and then >, </, legend, >.

lessons.title: Submit Button
lessons.interactiveContent:
To submit the input information, we add a button element inside the form. Code a button with the text "Register" at the bottom of the form.

Make sure to pick <button>, followed by Register, and finally </button>.

lessons.title: Question: Form Structure
lessons.interactiveContent:
What makes up a form structure?

A form element with input elements and a submit button insideA div element with form elements inside

A form element with input elements and a submit button inside.

lessons.title: Question: Form Element
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this code?

Missing closing tag for the form element </form>The inputs should be type email

Missing closing tag for the form element </form>.

lessons.title: Question: Form Inputs
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display?

A form for the user to input their name and date of birthA form for the user to input their name and phone number

A form for the user to input their name and date of birth.

lessons.title: Question: Fieldset
lessons.interactiveContent:
What do we use the fieldset element for?

We use a fieldset to group related inputs togetherWe use a fieldset to create an input in the form

We use a fieldset to group related inputs together.

lessons.title: Question: Legend
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the fieldset caption in the following code?

Student InfoStudent ID

Student Info.

lessons.title: Question: Submit Button
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this form?

The form is missing a submit buttonThe inputs should be type "submit"

The form is missing a submit button.

lessons.title: Exercise: Form Structure
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the form by coding the form element opening tag.

Make sure to type <form>.

lessons.title: Exercise: Form Element
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finish creating the form by coding the form element closing tag.

Make sure to type </form>.

lessons.title: Exercise: Form Inputs
lessons.interactiveContent:
Allow the user to pick a date by making the input type="date".

Make sure to type type="date".

lessons.title: Exercise: Fieldset
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a fieldset to group the user's contact information.

Make sure to pick < followed by fieldset and then >, </, fieldset, >.

lessons.title: Exercise: Legend
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a legend with the caption Employee Details for the employee fields.

Make sure to pick <legend>, followed by Employee Details, and finally </legend>.

lessons.title: Exercise: Submit Button
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a button with text Send for the user to submit their inquiry.

Make sure to pick <button>, followed by Send, and finally </button>.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: Websites come to life with user input: when visitors add comments, send messages, or share posts with their friends.

lessons.title: The input element
lessons.interactiveContent:
We've briefly learned that we can get user input with the input element. Let's get into more details. For now, code an input in the form.

Make sure to pick <input>.

lessons.title: Input text
lessons.interactiveContent:
For text, we set the type attribute to "text" to make the input element a text field.

Make sure to pick type, followed by =, and finally "text".

lessons.title: The text area element
lessons.interactiveContent:
input elements can only be text fields with a single line. To create a multiple-line text area, we use the textarea element.

Create a text area using the <textarea> and </textarea> tags.

Make sure to pick <textarea>, followed by </textarea>.

lessons.title: Controlling the text area size
lessons.interactiveContent:
To control the size of the text area, we use the rows attribute to set the rows of text and cols attribute to set the number of characters.

Set the rows attribute to "3" and the cols attribute to "15".

Make sure to pick "3", followed by "15".

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why is it difficult for users to know what to type in these text fields?

Because the placeholder attributes are missingBecause the closing tags are missing

Because the placeholder attributes are missing.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which element is a multiple-line text field?

<textarea></textarea><input type="text">

Make sure to pick <textarea></textarea>.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why is this text area not displaying the correct number of columns?

It uses the wrong attribute for columnsIt misses the placeholder attribute

It uses the wrong attribute for columns.

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display the input element with placeholder="City" below the other input element by using the <br> tag.

Make sure to pick <br>, followed by <input type="text" placeholder="City">.

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a text field for a single line of text.

Make sure to pick input.

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set the type attributes to "text" and the placeholder attribute to "Credit card name".

Make sure to pick "text", followed by "Credit card name".

lessons.title: Example 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Define a placeholder for the text area by coding placeholder.

Make sure to type placeholder.
